abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, audit project ratings are
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development. The principal conclusions from
            the audit relate to the longer term issues of funding in
            support of global biodiversity, the use of the gene bank,
            and the importance of the institutional background to the
            project. The issue of funding global biodiversity,
            regardless of honors granted by international agencies, and
            nongovernmental organizations, including the Global
            Environment Facility (GEF), remains financially unresolved
            for the long term. This leads to question how incremental
            costs, required to achieve global benefits, are to be
            covered, since the principal costs are ongoing maintenance
            of the resources, rather than one-time investments. Thus, it
            is found appropriate for the GEF to raise this issue,
            highlighted by project reviews. The substantial investment
            the Gene Bank already is, and its degree of sophistication,
            and considerable expertise in the maintenance of perennial
            plant germ-plasm, suggest it may be time for the GEF to
            consider how this type of facility fits into its overall
            program of protection of species, and genetic material, and
            how useful it may be for the international plant research
            community. The apparent structure of research funding in the
            former socialist countries, seems to provide too large a
            role to the academies of science, which view research from
            an academic viewpoint, rather than from a problem-solving
            perspective, and consequently results did not develop
            operational programs, inconsistent with project objectives.

1089538.trustfund:
TF032718-POLAND - FOREST BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF031280-POLAND -FORESTRY BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF021685-GET-FOREST BIODIVERSITY
            PROTECTION PROJ.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forest Biodiversity
            Protection Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance during implementation was also satisfactory, and
            the recipient's performance was more satisfactory
            during appraisal and implementation than during
            identification and preparation. Some lessons learned
            included: the project was intended to test a balance of
            in-situ and ex-situ conservation, depending upon the
            imminence of the threat on the environment. To date, it has
            demonstrated that in-situ conservation is more
            cost-effective than ex-situ conservation, and that the time
            horizon of the threat and outside social and economic forces
            are factors to consider when allocating scarce resources.
            Furthermore, it teaches that without directly linking
            in-situ restoration activities to ex-situ conservation, the
            usefulness of the latter is jeopardized. The project
            suffered from a lack of proactive, thoughtful
            outreach/public relation activities at local as well as
            national level. It must be recognized, however, that at the
            local level, after a certain resistance was overcome, the
            project was able to generate some important support for
            Bialowieza Primeval Forest (BPF) through outreach activities
            like man and the biosphere.

731754.trustfund:
TF032718-POLAND - FOREST BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF031280-POLAND -FORESTRY BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF021685-GET-FOREST BIODIVERSITY
            PROTECTION PROJ.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Forest Biodiversity Protection
            project will initiate programs to conserve the biodiversity
            of key endangered forests and will provide institutional
            support to the Ministry of Environment, Natural Resources
            and Forestry (MENRF) to undertake biodiversity conservation
            management activities, including the establishment of a
            forestry gene bank.  The GEF operation will support
            Poland's effort to protect its forest ecosystems.
            Selection of the parks, reserves and zones under the project
            are based on agreed conservation priorities.  Project
            investments include: (i) institutional support to the MENRF
            to enable it to carry out its biodiversity conservation
            management activities including the establishment of
            facilities for ex-situ conservation of genetic material in
            the Sudety forests of Southwest Poland and for a
            biodiversity protection program for Bialowieza Primeval
            Forest (BPF) ecosystem of Eastern Poland; and (ii)
            investment in programs to preserve endangered forest
            ecosystems for biodiversity conservation through provision
            of funding for pilot investments in air and soil monitoring
            equipment, a forest gene bank and related archival nursery
            equipment, land planning equipment, air and soil monitoring
            equipment (fixed and mobile), protected area planning,
            financial support for a program for supporting transition to
            ecological agriculture for farmers operating within the BPF,
            and professional development, training and consulting services.
